story:
Please read: I am so excited we have reached the $500 mark and I thank you all for the support. My ultimate goal is to reach $6,000 and 100 backers in the next month- every copy purchased is a step closer to the publishing of the book. 

Any and all of the money goes towards the cover design, launch party and so on. I appreciate all the help. 

Story of My Book

The F Word

My name is Amya Gulati and I am the author of The F Word. This topic can be taboo for many people, depending on their background, and I wanted to write something that I know a lot of people can relate to and find peace in. 

I want to help people understand why we still need feminism, why many people turn to it, and why it is a global issue. There are so many facets to the subject and while it is so complex and my book doesn’t even cover the half of it, some insight on feminism could truly change a lot of people’s perspectives and outlooks on life and how we treat others.

In this book, you'll learn about:

- How myths can have a detrimental effect on society 

- The increasing numbers in sex work in Russia

- Child marriages in the Middle East

People that are just as passionate about feminism as I am would enjoy this book. I think that people that don’t particularly know a lot about feminism but are open to learning or trying to understand some perspective of it would find the book interesting. The whole idea is that the reader approaches the book with an open-mind- I don’t want people reading this book to feel like they have to agree with me on everything, but I think people that can approach this book with some level-headed thinking and openness would definitely enjoy it more. 

The F Word is a non-fiction book that speaks to feminists, those passionate about social issues, and those who may be exploring feminism and gender equality for the first time.

The Book- The F Word 

This book is written in three parts: 

Part 1 contains the introduction and additional chapters. I provide the reader with my reasons for writing this book, and why feminism is something that is important to me. Chapters 1 to 7 outline American first-wave feminism and its many evolutions. The first part of the book also outlines insidious societal constructs and practices such as slut-shaming, cat-calling, and rejection in dating. 


Part 2 contains Chapters 8 to 12. These chapters focus in on sexism and misogyny in traditional cultures such as India, Pakistan, South Africa, and other Middle Eastern countries. It outlines the practice of acid attacks, rape culture, child marriage, and young mothers, and why and how these customs came to be. 

Part 3 contains Chapters 13 to 15. This last part of the book takes a look at how poverty especially targets women, regardless of their race, nationality, or ethnicity. Chapter 14 in particular discusses sex work in Russia, and how many women in these Eastern European countries turn to prostitution due to their failing economy and lack of education. 

What I Need & What You'll Get

This book will be published with New Degree Press. I set up the pre-order tiers to help cover the costs for publishing my book. Money raised will go towards the following:
 

The Editor I will work with to revise and publish my manuscript in July 2020. 

The Cover Design of my Book - the mockups you see currently are a placeholder!

The Layout Design for the interior of my book, both physical copy and e-book formats. 

The Copyediting for My Book - to help polish the grammar and spelling prior to publication. 

The Launch & Promotion Efforts for my book - when I ultimately publish my book in the summer.  

When I pre-sell 100 copies of my book, I will publish The F Word. When I pre-sell 150 copies of my book, I will also publish an audiobook. When I pre-sell 200 copies of my book, I will publish a hardcover edition.

I am also offering some exclusive rewards for people who pre-order my book now:

- You will receive a personally signed copy of my book when I publish

- A Personal, handwritten thank you note for pre-ordering my book

- Your Name will appear in a Special, Acknowledgements Section of my book (“with Special Thanks to”)

- Early access to the Introduction of my Book and my entire manuscript, with the opportunity to review it and give me early feedback

- The opportunity to help give me feedback and be involved in selecting my cover

- I will do a book topic/workshop seminar where I will share experience the experiences of writing my book

- And more...

A little edit: There is an error in the perks included in the purchasing of an e-book! You will not receive a paperback edition of the book, but you will be able to get a e-book version, join the beta reader community, read my introduction early, help me select my cover, and get recognition in the acknowledgements section of the book.

About the Author

Amya Gulati is a student at Rutgers University. She is currently studying for a Bachelor's degree in Journalism and Political Science. Amya has always called herself a feminist, but wanted to take a deeper look at what the movement is really about and why it is a global issue. While she is very passionate about politics and social issues, she also enjoys relaxing and taking a break from all outside world, whether it be spending time with her friends and family or going out for a walk with her poodle. 

For more information you can connect with Amya at amyagulati@gmail.com or follow her twitter @amyagulati. 

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge with publishing a book is delivering the finished book to the backer, specifically my mailing of the book to you. I have eliminated this risk by building into the campaign the mailing and shipping costs of your signed copies to you within each pre-order tier.

The risk of delivering the pre-sale copies of my book is contingent on the publisher we use. I will be working closely with New Degree Press to make sure we get the earliest possible ship date of the signed book copy to you. We will keep all pre-sale backers up-to-date as my book hits each key milestone and publishes. You will know when the copies of my book you pre-ordered are expected to ship.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

Please Share my Pre-sale Campaign on Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn with your friends, family and network. Please use #TheFWord and tag me as well as my publisher, New Degree Press so we can help amplify your efforts.

You can easily share my Pre-Sale Campaign Page via Indiegogo at the top of the page

Please share my book to 5 friends, family members, or co-workers who you think would enjoy it. Please do this as a text message or Direct Message on social media.

Thank you so much of all of your love and support!

Thanks again,
Amya Gulati

story:
“Amy, just be yourself!”

That was what adults kept telling me when I was a preteen girl wondering who I was, where I fit in, and what my whole purpose in life was supposed to be. Good advice—only problem was, I didn’t know what it meant to “be yourself!”

Maybe you struggled with the same issues and questions at that age. I know I see a lot of preteen and teen girls who do, and that’s what inspired me to develop a special journal just for them: Be Yourself: A Journal for Catholic Girls.

 

“Be Who God Meant You To Be!”

If you’ve followed my blog, Prayer Wine Chocolate, you know that I am a huge fan of journaling as a means of self-expression and discovery. Like many journals for girls, Be Yourself! offers lots of ways for readers to explore questions about their identity, worthiness, belonging, and purpose. But Be Yourself! also accompanies girls, connecting them with the wisdom of the Catholic Church—and some of its most wise and holy women. Women like St. Catherine of Siena, who said: “Be who God meant you to be, and you will set the world on fire!”

Be Yourself! includes more than 80 pages of fun activities, quizzes, personal “letters” from women saints, and journaling opportunities that girls will love. Quotes from the Catechism of the Catholic Church and Scripture provide girls with wisdom from their faith tradition—wisdom that they can use as they explore what it means to “be yourself” in the light of God’s will for them.

The Be Yourself! journal guides the reader to three essential truths:

  1. That at bottom, her identity is grounded in God’s love for her.
  2. That in God’s sight, she has been beautifully and wonderfully made. (This is such an important truth for girls to embrace, especially at a time when they’re so critical of themselves and others!)
  3. That each girl was made by God for a special purpose—a mission “to be the hands and heart of God”—and that God has provided her with everything she needs to accomplish that mission.

This journal won’t provide girls with any “final answer” to their questions, but my hope is that it will guide them to seek those answers in the light of God’s love, guided by the Church.

 

Let’s Make Something Beautiful!

Speaking of beautifully made . . . in order to make this journal as appealing as possible to girls, we’re hiring a professional book designer: Laurie Nelson, of Agape Design Studios. Laurie’s design work has been delighting kids for more than twenty years. Laurie is working with veteran Catholic artist Vicki Shuck, who will be providing us with portraits of key women saints, as well as gorgeous coloring pages of those saints.

Together, we’re going to make Be Yourself! a journal that girls will love to read, share, and make their own. You can see some of the preliminary page designs at the bottom of this post.

In order to get Be Yourself! into the hands of Catholic girls, we need to cover the costs of design and production work. You can help us raise the money we need to move forward by making a donation in exchange for one or more copies of Be Yourself!, or any of the other great thank-you gifts we’re offering as part of this crowdfunding campaign.

If you can’t give as much as you’d like, don’t worry—whatever you give is a vote of confidence in this project!

 

Thank You

I want to personally thank you in advance for supporting my passion to help girls discover their beautiful identity in the Lord. My prayer is that your gift to this project connects your heart in a special way to the girl who is struggling to fit in, the girl who questions her self-worth—but who is about to discover joy and confidence in God’s love for her.

 

P.S. Here's a Look at the Table of Contents

Hey, if you're curious about what all is in the book, here's a table of contents, followed by some preliminary page and cover designs. We're still working on the journal (especially the cover), so the final product may differ somewhat from what you see here.

 

How to Use this Book

 

Chapter 1:  Who You REALLY Are

Beauty Basics

God’s Creation

God’s Creation and You (Part 1)

Coloring Page: The Lord’s Creation

God’s Creation and You: (Part 2) – Would You Rather . . .

Chapter 4:  Prayer

Present Prayer

Coloring Page: Thank You God

Chapter 5: Talents and Gifts

Finding Your Gifts and Talents

Saints and Their Hobbies: Write Your Own Novena

Coloring Page: Never Give Up

Coloring Page: She is Clothed with Strength . . .

 

Chapter 6: Feelings

Hurt Feelings

Forgiveness

Questions? Thoughts?

Paper Recess: Favorites

Thinking About the Future

Praying About the Future

 

Chapter 7: Your Life

God Loves You!

Love God Back!

Coloring Page: Love the Lord Your God . . .

Scavenger Hunt

Coloring Page: Most Sacred Heart of Jesus

A Word From Your Blessed Mother

Coloring Page: Immaculate Heart of Mary

Coloring Page: The Blessed Mother

 

Chapter 8: Inspiration

Coloring Page: Walk by Faith, Not By Sight

Coloring Page: Proverbs 31:26

Coloring Page: Galatians 5:22

Coloring Page: Dear Lord, Help me with my studies

Coloring Page: Everything is Possible With Faith

Dear Jesus . . .

The Beginning . . .

 

Preliminary Page Designs

Here are a few designs we've been playing with...still working on it! First, a cover possibility:

 

And here are some of the preliminary interior page designs:

story:
In 2010 I traveled to Spain to walk the Camino de Santiago. I made it a few miles past half way (262 mi.) and got sick (wicked sinus infection from spending an afternoon in a hyper-smoky bar: it was raining outside, it was Sunday, and everything else was closed) and after a few days of battling a worsening condition I ended up flying home to Boise, Idaho. Since then I have completed my book of the first half of the Camino (a two year process), have completed what I am calling the Middle Book, which is of my travails and inner journey since returning, and now I feel I must return to Spain to finish my walk on the French route (the classic route) to Santiago de Compostela, and through to Muxia on the Atlantic coast, and then walk the Camino del Norte also. I am writing of the physical journey, Spain, some of the history, but more importantly I am writing about my inner journey which can only be accessed by the endless walk and endless meditative quiet one finds on the Camino.

Walking the Camino de Santiago from Saint Jean Pied du Port to Santiago de Compostela,  lends itself to inner exploration. Adding El Camino del Norte, which is less developed, requiring longer days, offers an opportunity to explore even deeper levels of insight, pain and endurance. I need to write about it. I need to journal my days, my feelings, and revelations. I hope to write an enduring novel of a world class experience which will inspire others to embark on their own spiritual paths. .

As I walk I will email my daily journal entries, and when I complete the book, those who have donated will receive an autographed copy.

story:
"I think there's something wrong with Miss Hunter."  With those words, the six adorkable main characters of my children's novel "Hunter the Horrible" are initiated into an ancient guild of vampire hunters.  My children's novel debuted is July, and has experienced an encouraging level of success.  It is a fun, well-written piece with lots of humor and unexepected twists.  Of extra interest is that one of the characters is, like my oldest son, autistic, showing children that one can be a hero not just in spite of, but because of one's differences. 

I have worked very hard to make contacts at various venues and am not in a difficult 
position.  There is demand for me and for my product.  However, to fill that demand 
there are certain upfront costs that I simply cannot afford.  It is incredibly difficult to build 
momentum for a new work, and I am hesitant to decline sales or promotional 
opportunities. However, without this campaign, I will have no choice but to clear a great 
deal of my schedule for this fall.  This schedule can be found at 
www.hunterthehorrible.com under the "Join the Guild" tab. 

I am asking for $4,000.  First and foremost, I need books.  If I am attending an event that is paid for by my publisher, he also pays for the books that I sell.  However, if I am attending an event that I have lined up for myself, I must buy the books.  My stock of books is getting dangerously low.  I would like to purchase at least 200 books.  Secondly, I am looking for transportation.  I have four children, and two of them have special needs.  Therefore, travel and hotels can be difficult.  The long corridors and floors that are often slippery are difficult for my daughter who walks with canes and braces.  My son is autistic, and changes in environment are difficult for him.  Also, hotels are incredibly expensive and not every venue includes complementary accommodations.  To address this issue, I have found an airstream camper available through www.opus-transactions.com for $2700.  The details of this camper can be found at http://indianapolis.craigslist.org/rvs/3931399371.html.   The remaining monies will be allocated to table fees and fuel expenses.  While I work hard to volunteer or make deals so that my table costs are minimal, there are still occasional expenses.  However, I only attend these events when research as assured me that sales and exposure will be worth the cost. If I do not reach my entire goal, funds will be allocated first to books, then to immediate hotel costs and a savings account towards the purchase of a camper. 

I want you to be as excited about this project as I am, so I have set up some perks that I 
think that you will really enjoy.  
I have been to several events, and at each event I have been the bestselling author. My 
book is very well-received and I have worked very hard to refine a sales technique that 
excites buyers.  Also, people are very pleased with their purchase; I have received 
numerous fan letters and favorable reviews.  Therefore, I am confident that, if I can 
continue to attend various venues, the popularity of "Hunter the Horrible" will continue to 
grow.  
If you like this project, but cannot contribute at this time, please share this link, like me on Facebook, or join the Guild at www.hunterthehorrible.com.  Thank you so much.
story_txt:
"I think there's something wrong with Miss Hunter."  With those words, the six adorkable main characters of my children's novel "Hunter the Horrible" are initiated into an ancient guild of vampire hunters.  My children's novel debuted is July, and has experienced an encouraging level of success.  It is a fun, well-written piece with lots of humor and unexepected twists.  Of extra interest is that one of the characters is, like my oldest son, autistic, showing children that one can be a hero not just in spite of, but because of one's differences. 
I have worked very hard to make contacts at various venues and am not in a difficult 
position.  There is demand for me and for my product.  However, to fill that demand 
there are certain upfront costs that I simply cannot afford.  It is incredibly difficult to build 
momentum for a new work, and I am hesitant to decline sales or promotional 
opportunities. However, without this campaign, I will have no choice but to clear a great 
deal of my schedule for this fall.  This schedule can be found at 
www.hunterthehorrible.com under the "Join the Guild" tab. 
I am asking for $4,000.  First and foremost, I need books.  If I am attending an event that is paid for by my publisher, he also pays for the books that I sell.  However, if I am attending an event that I have lined up for myself, I must buy the books.  My stock of books is getting dangerously low.  I would like to purchase at least 200 books.  Secondly, I am looking for transportation.  I have four children, and two of them have special needs.  Therefore, travel and hotels can be difficult.  The long corridors and floors that are often slippery are difficult for my daughter who walks with canes and braces.  My son is autistic, and changes in environment are difficult for him.  Also, hotels are incredibly expensive and not every venue includes complementary accommodations.  To address this issue, I have found an airstream camper available through www.opus-transactions.com for $2700.  The details of this camper can be found at http://indianapolis.craigslist.org/rvs/3931399371.html.   The remaining monies will be allocated to table fees and fuel expenses.  While I work hard to volunteer or make deals so that my table costs are minimal, there are still occasional expenses.  However, I only attend these events when research as assured me that sales and exposure will be worth the cost. If I do not reach my entire goal, funds will be allocated first to books, then to immediate hotel costs and a savings account towards the purchase of a camper. 
I want you to be as excited about this project as I am, so I have set up some perks that I 
think that you will really enjoy.  
I have been to several events, and at each event I have been the bestselling author. My 
book is very well-received and I have worked very hard to refine a sales technique that 
excites buyers.  Also, people are very pleased with their purchase; I have received 
numerous fan letters and favorable reviews.  Therefore, I am confident that, if I can 
continue to attend various venues, the popularity of "Hunter the Horrible" will continue to 
grow.  
If you like this project, but cannot contribute at this time, please share this link, like me on Facebook, or join the Guild at www.hunterthehorrible.com.  Thank you so much.

story:
Here's the Deal

      "If you could ask everyone you met just one question, what would you ask?"

Thousands have participated and I would love to hear your question! I set up the website www.justonequestion.org to put all the great questions I've gathered out to the public.

And here's where it started: In 2006, after finishing a Master's degree at Harvard University, I decided to step away from academia and pursue my own project and go out and discover America. I hopped in my little red Honda and the rest is history!

I love sharing the project and am excited about the book, but to be honest, contrary to this very public campaign I'm not a big self-sales kind of guy. All the photographs and edited interviews and website-building have been done on my own time. I've made this huge project come together without any external support and always as a labor of love. I have never done any aspect of this project for money and have spent my own cash to get the book edited, have written and stamped 564 letters to famous people for their questions on postcards and even spent the 6 months living out of my car to do the project. And believe me, I'm not complaining: IT'S BEEN A BLAST!

I'm doing this because the story is so fun and the questions are so interesting that I really, truly think you'll enjoy it, that it should be out in the world.

You're being asked to support this self-publishing project rather than me going to a big corporate publisher because I really want to do this project with the same Do-It-Yourself ethos I so appreciate in the art and works I surround myself with. This is the real deal. Support grassroots art!

What I Need & What You Get

The $3,721 is not something I pulled out of the air. Let me break down the costs in more detail:

  • The Mill City Basic publishing $2,497 that includes all kinds of important details that make the book professional: ISBN #, Copyright registration, and custom interior formatting.
  • Conversion to all E-Book formats is $799 and that's an essential piece to this project as well. Sadly, the print book may truly be dying.
  • Kirkus Review: $425. It's a small piece of the puzzle, but a solid Kirkus review can really help sell this book to the true literary world (librarians, etc.)
  • The perks are great! Really it's mostly about the book, but honestly, I don't make too much off the book alone. Consider pledging for a signed copy, or the audiobook!
  • Here's an important caveat: the book won't be ready by Christmas, so pledges that come in a reasonable time prior to the 25th of December I will send out a 'Place Holder' gift to be given at Christmas. When the book is completed in March, I'll send out the physical copies as soon as I possibly can.

Other Ways You Can Help

Just because you can’t contribute monetarily doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about Just One Question!
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Pass the link on by email to anyone you think might be interested!

               Thanks so much! I can't wait to share this story with the world!

story:
It's a long way from Florida, Toto.  When not dazzling the internet with well placed curse words and snarky insights on the state of humankind, Natallia can be found taking long walks with full bottles of red wine, hugging trees or doing "the worm" at weddings.  No, really, she does the "worm" at weddings.                                                                                               

                          

    Born and raised in Philly.  Cut his teeth in New York.  Now lives in LA.  After spending years in the entertainment biz, Billy is making his transition to co-author and couldn't be more excited.  Other hobbies include making inanimate objects talk, holding his breath when he going through tunnels, and collecting shiny objects.  They make him happy.           

 

                     

 

... I grew up living and hearing the same romantic story most young girls in America hear: watch Cinderella, become a member of the girl scouts, study hard in school, become Cinderella, meet the man of your dreams, fall in love, get a great job, have 2.5 babies and live in a cottage made out of gingerbread and candy canes.

Well, none of that happened, no matter how much I held out for that gingerbread cottage!  In fact, by 26, my life was a complete and utter shit show.

I was 40 pounds overweight, had an eating disorder, was struggling with the sudden death of my father and my sister's severe alchoholism, was in one bad relationship after the next and eventually was living in my car! Oh Cinderella, where art thou?!

At 28, I vowed to live life by my own rules, learn from the past, and get out of my Toyota! My way of coping and fighting back was to tell my story to other people, coworkers, friends, and even strangers.

With each person I told my story to, I realized we all go through bullshit, it's called life.  But no one prepares you for it.

So, I began writing down ways to deal with life's challenges. And through the advent of social media, I began posting them. The response I got was overwhelminlg similar, “You should write a book.”

So here it is! 

 

 

The ultimate goal is to redefine the fairtyale by pulling away the curtain and talking about the real-life B.S. that gets overlooked in school.

This book is a basic survival guide to life in your twenties and thirties; addressing practical skills like health, money, relationships, beauty, happiness, overcoming difficulites and utlimately how to be the best version of yourself.  

Your contribution to this campaign will help bring to life the curriculum that we all wish we learned a long time ago.

One of the books biggest assets is using cartoons to talk about life's bullshit.  

Cartoons get away with a lot more than people.  And rightfully so... they're cartoons! They're fun, and believe it or not, people are more willing to hear advice from a purple horse than an actual person :) Hakuna Matata, anyone?

         

I've done a hell of a lot of research over the last two years. And there's one thing that I've learned for sure; shooting for the stars is not cheap.

 

So, I've decided to do an e-book for two reasons:  one, e-books are the way of the future. But more importantly, e-books keep it environmentally sound!  Less trees, less plastic, more fun!   

 

After crunching the numbers, $7,500 smackers is what we're looking at for illustrator, graphic designer, editor, etc. to launch this book.  That's where you come in!  

 

I am always humbled at the generostiy of the human spirit.  I can't tell you how many people have helped me along during the process of writing this book.  The only way to truly repay them is to get it finished.  But I can't do it alone.  

 

If in any way, you can help support the funding of this book, I will be forever grateful and humbled by your generousity.  

Social Networking is the best way to show your love and spread the word about the book. 

It's easy to do.  Copy and paste the tab just below the video and you can help get the word out.  And then you will be awesome.  And we will love you. 

 

                      

 

"Shit101 is where I go for laughs, inspiration and knowledge that I can actually use, and do!"            -Whitney Ayers, Raw Food Nutritionist and Blogger

"The search is over.  Finally a goddam writer who can write about anything and keeps me engaged." -Gabe Berman, Author Of "Live Like A Fruit Fly"

"Love your perspective, love your humour.  Every 20-Something needs a Shit101 survival guide."     -Lisa Diane Wright, Blogger at LifeStyleofBeauty.com

"Young people need some sort of guide after major shifts and transitions in their life to keep straight and not suffer like some of us have.  I hope to read your book soon!"   
-Kevin Aguirre Rodriguez, 20-Something Super Fan

story:
El Caso

Soy Benito Alonso, director del Ministerio Ayudando a los Olvidados, y por medio de esta obra le brindamos alimento y apoyo a personas sin hogar en distintos puntos del área Metropolitana.
 
Llevo 8 1/2 años alimentando a la población de adictos y deambulantes (personas sin hogar); en la semana les damos almuerzos y los fines de semana desayunos. Por un periodo de 5 años mas o menos, hemos hecho gestiones con el gobierno para tratar de adquirir la propiedad identificada pero no nos han ayudado.
 
Es mi sueño el poder establecer el comedor para que nuestros participantes tengan un lugar seguro donde reciban una comida segura diariamente y se puedan asear y puedan recibir tratamiento.

Pueden donar por medio de esta plataforma social o a la cuenta de banco 300-448-3838 (Cuenta de Cheques) del Banco Santander.

Un pequeño resume para los que quieran contribuir

  • Dios tocó mi vida y puso en mi corazón el deseo de trabajar con los deambulantes llevándoles desayunos a estos seres humanos que han quedado en el olvido por muchas personas. Junto a mi han estado mi esposa Mirelis Laguna y mi hijo Beniel Alonso. Comenzamos a llevarles desayunos a los deambulantes del área de Berwind, Río Piedras, el 26 de septiembre de 2004 y para el verano del año 2005 se nos unió el hermano Harry Almódovar y su familia. Hasta el día de hoy y sin interés alguno todos estamos ofreciendo el servicio voluntariamente para la Gloria de Dios..
  • Cuando comenzamos hace cinco años dábamos desayunos todos los domingos y luego, al ver la necesidad de esta población añadimos los sábados. Desde hace tres años, para el verano de 2008, comenzamos a darles almuerzos todos los lunes y en la actualidad le ofrecemos almuerzo los miércoles también. Podemos decir que lo que comenzamos con un día, Dios nos ha prosperado y hoy brindamos un servicio semanal de cuatro días; o sea, sábados y domingos desayunos y lunes y miércoles almuerzos. Todo esto para la Gloria de Dios.

Pueden donar por medio de esta plataforma social o a la cuenta de banco 300-448-3838 (Cuenta de Cheques) del Banco Santander.

El Impacto

Impactamos una población de 125-150 deambulantes de las áreas de Carolina y Río Piedras: en Carolina los Residenciales Torres de Sabana y Sabana Abajo y en Río Piedras los Residenciales Los Peñas, Jardines de Sellés, El Polvorín, Berwind y Monte Hatillo, el cual hace tres meses también estamos dándoles el servicio.

Comenzamos este Ministerio dando servicio a los deambulantes, adictos a drogas, homosexuales, lesbianas, prostitutas, pacientes de HIV y todo aquel ser humano que tenga la necesidad de nuestros servicios. Ha sido una experiencia extraordinaria que Dios nos ha permitido trabajar con esta población que tanta necesidad tiene, adicional les damos sus compritas de ves en cuando y todo el que se nos acerca que quiere hacer un cambio en su vida lo llevamos a hogares de rehabilitación.

Toda persona que Dios le toque su corazón y quiera cooperar, su donativo es 100% deducible de la planilla ya que el Ministerio cumple con todos los requisitos que exige el Gobierno de Puerto Rico y sería una satisfacción personal que puedan contribuir con la causa ya que deseamos poderle hacer una oferta al personal de Scotiabank y agradeceremos su cooperación eternamente.

Pueden donar por medio de esta plataforma social o a la cuenta de banco 300-448-3838 (Cuenta de Cheques) del Banco Santander.

Que necesitaríamos Y Que recibirían los Contribuyentes un Cambio

Toda persona que Dios le toque su corazón y quiera cooperar, su donativo es 100% deducible de la planilla ya que el Ministerio cumple con todos los requisitos que exige el Gobierno de Puerto Rico y sería una satisfacción personal que puedan contribuir con la causa ya que deseamos poderle hacer una oferta al personal de Scotiabank y agradeceremos su cooperación eternamente.

Pueden donar por medio de esta plataforma social o a la cuenta de banco 300-448-3838 (Cuenta de Cheques) del Banco Santander.

story:
Who We Are and What We Do

We are the Wicked Wordsmiths of the West, a group of writers and wannabe writers who joined forces after NaNoWriMo 2012 to help each other maintain the creative spark and write as much as possible. Two years later, the original small group has grown to over 20 members, meets on a regular basis, and has recently published our first anthology on Amazon. 

We want writers to flex their creative muscles, to be inspired to write more often, and, most importantly, to feel comfortable sharing their work with others. By assigning helpful, although somewhat goofy, writing prompts, by competing in monthly word count challenges, and by sharing the more-than-occasional cup of coffee, we are working to create an inviting, supportive community of authors throughout our tri-state area.

What We Need 

We are looking for funding for several needs:

  • Non-profit status: in order for us to operate more efficiently and to ensure that all of our funds are going right back into our community, we need to apply for non-profit status from the federal government. This, unfortunately, requires funds.
  • NaNoWriMo 2014: While NaNo and our group are not one in the same, our group directly funds the NaNo activities during the month of November. We recruit heavily in November and help newbies survive NaNo as well as encourage them to follow their writing dreams as far as they want to go. 
  • Group Activities: While we've never had enough funding to do it, we have long desired to travel to writing conferences together, to bring in special lecturers, and to attend workshops as a group. As we are inclusive of everyone, we don't like taking part in these activities unless everyone can attend. Funding will make our dreams become reality! 
  • Anthology 2015: We are already planning our next anthology! Our horror anthology taught us a lot and we hope to make the next one even better. While group members generously supported the printing with their own personal funds, funding would allow us to get more of our books into local stores and libraries, enabling even more networking with potential writers!

The Impact

We live in the heart of Appalachia. Writers here have a unique voice, as well as a unique set of obstacles to publication. We firmly believe that all people, regardless of race, socioeconomic status, age, religion, ability or opportunity should have the right to get their stories heard. 

 We provide that outlet.

By supporting our group, you are helping a team of local writers find their place in the world. You are helping to inspire the future Poes, Dickens, Follets, and Rowlings of our area. You are supporting a diverse group of individuals who feel that, through fraternity and hard work, anything is possible. You are supporting a group of writers who are dedicated to working together to improve their writing skills, find their voice, and reach out to their community.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Please, share us on Facebook or twitter. Help us get the word out! And if you have a moment, check out our anthology. It is available on Amazon in both book form and on the kindle. Most importantly, if you're a writer, write! The world deserves your story- join us in putting it out there.
story_txt:
Who We Are and What We Do We are the Wicked Wordsmiths of the West, a group of writers and wannabe writers who joined forces after NaNoWriMo 2012 to help each other maintain the creative spark and write as much as possible. Two years later, the original small group has grown to over 20 members, meets on a regular basis, and has recently published our first anthology on Amazon. 
We want writers to flex their creative muscles, to be inspired to write more often, and, most importantly, to feel comfortable sharing their work with others. By assigning helpful, although somewhat goofy, writing prompts, by competing in monthly word count challenges, and by sharing the more-than-occasional cup of coffee, we are working to create an inviting, supportive community of authors throughout our tri-state area.   What We Need  We are looking for funding for several needs: 

Non-profit status: in order for us to operate more efficiently and to ensure that all of our funds are going right back into our community, we need to apply for non-profit status from the federal government. This, unfortunately, requires funds. 
NaNoWriMo 2014: While NaNo and our group are not one in the same, our group directly funds the NaNo activities during the month of November. We recruit heavily in November and help newbies survive NaNo as well as encourage them to follow their writing dreams as far as they want to go.  
Group Activities: While we've never had enough funding to do it, we have long desired to travel to writing conferences together, to bring in special lecturers, and to attend workshops as a group. As we are inclusive of everyone, we don't like taking part in these activities unless everyone can attend. Funding will make our dreams become reality! 

Anthology 2015: We are already planning our next anthology! Our horror anthology taught us a lot and we hope to make the next one even better. While group members generously supported the printing with their own personal funds, funding would allow us to get more of our books into local stores and libraries, enabling even more networking with potential writers! 
  The Impact We live in the heart of Appalachia. Writers here have a unique voice, as well as a unique set of obstacles to publication. We firmly believe that all people, regardless of race, socioeconomic status, age, religion, ability or opportunity should have the right to get their stories heard. 
 We provide that outlet.
By supporting our group, you are helping a team of local writers find their place in the world. You are helping to inspire the future Poes, Dickens, Follets, and Rowlings of our area. You are supporting a diverse group of individuals who feel that, through fraternity and hard work, anything is possible. You are supporting a group of writers who are dedicated to working together to improve their writing skills, find their voice, and reach out to their community.
  Other Ways You Can Help Please, share us on Facebook or twitter. Help us get the word out! And if you have a moment, check out our anthology. It is available on Amazon in both book form and on the kindle. Most importantly, if you're a writer, write! The world deserves your story- join us in putting it out there.

story:
Go To Black

The Book

More than a half-century ago, the United States found itself torn apart over the issue of civil rights.  In the decades leading up to the 1950's, the treatment of blacks in the American South went unreported in the mainstream press.  The murder of Emmit Till changed all that as a nation saw -for the first time- the horrors inflicted upon their countrymen who, save for the color of their skin, were no different from themselves. The civil rights battles that waged from lunch counters in Greensboro to a bus stop in Montgomery to a high school in Little Rock were well documented by national broadcasters who, at the end of the day, returned home to New York or Boston or Chicago.  Go To Black is the story of the local broadcast journalists who called those southern cities home.  It's a story about the men and women - the photographers, the producers, the reporters - who stood up for what was right in their home towns even as their bosses were telling them to stand down. 

The Author


Andrew Gobeil has been a broadcast journalist for nearly forty years.  As a high school student, he'd ride his bike to anchor the news on the Cape Cod radio station where he was employed part-time.  He worked -and paid- his way through Fitchburg State College in Massachusetts and, after graduation, was named one of the youngest NPR affiliate news directors in the country.  He made the jump from radio to television in the 1990s and, after a number of promotions, found himself as a Washington, DC correspondent for network of television stations.  He's interviewed presidents, walked through forest fires, flown into hurricanes and even taken the stick (briefly!) of an F-16.  His unique skills as a reporter, interviewer, editor and writer will serve him well as he produces the Go To Black project. A native of Cape Cod, Andrew fell in love with the South as soon as he arrived there.  Andrew's sons -16 year old Devin and 12 year old Jack- live in South Carolina.  

The Campaign

The heroes -and they were truly heroes- who tried to report the truth during these tumultuous times have aged considerably.  Their stories haven't been told in full, and time is passing far too quickly for us to hold out any longer.  Your support of the Go To Black campaign will allow us to travel and interview these men and women, record their words, and let their voices be heard.  With full funding, we'll be able to purchase the rights to broadcast reports they produced fifty years ago, produce web-based video updates on the interviews, and then write and publish the book Go To Black.  Ideally, we'd like to produce a companion web component that would include the interviews conducted this year combined with the pieces produced decades ago.       

The Appreciation 

Mere words can't begin to express our thanks for your assistance in funding this important campaign.  If you're unable to offer financial support to the endeavor, you can still help:

  • Get the word out! Mention (and link via the Indigogo share tools) us on Facebook, Twitter, and Pinterest.  To our friends in the media, book us on your talk shows, invite us on air, and/or produce stories about us to drum up support

story:
Kristy Rock is a 25 year old suffering from the life threatening genetic disorder 

Cystic Fibrosis, a disease which effects the respiratory and digestive systems. Despite 

having been through more in her 25 years than most would in a lifetime, Kristy 

manages to remain a happy positive person. During 2013 Kristy was admitted to 

hospital 11 times with the shortest stay being 14 days and the longest 6 weeks. 

Needless to say Kristy spends a lot of her time in a hospital bed. Being the inspiring 

soul she is, she would like to use this time to do something constructive, to write a 

book. Kristy wishes to write about the positive side of her illness, what she has learnt 

from it, and how she has dealt with it. She is hoping this will help her family, friends 

and others suffering from terminal and chronic illnesses find the positives from what 

most would see as a negative situation. 


Kristy had planned to begin writing her book on her ipad until she had saved enough 

money for the laptop she wanted. That plan was cut short when the ipad along with 

some of her other possessions and medications were stolen from her house when it 

was broken into just before Christmas last year. We are looking to raise enough money 

to help Kristy buy a good quality laptop to help aid her book writing dreams. Any extra 

money raised will go towards add ons for Kristy's laptop such as an external hard drive 

and internet connection. Each and every donation will be greatly appreciated. 

Thank you!

Each and every donation will be greatly appreciated. Thank you!

story:
UPDATES! STRETCH GOALS!

$3,000 ACHIEVED! We did it! I plan to donate any money raised after this point to the Medieval and Renaissance Studies Program at Mizzou travel fund to help other young scholars at MU make important trips of their own.

STRETCH GOAL #3 - ACHIEVED! At $2,750, Eric will shout every contributor's name - INCLUDING YOURS! - at Thingvale, site of the Althing!

STRETCH GOAL #2 - ACHIEVED! At $2,500, Eric will do an Icelandic Word of the Day video!

STRETCH GOAL #1 - ACHIEVED! At $2,000, Eric will do a daily Icelandic Photo Blog!

Dear god, this thing has been up for about 27 hours and we're already at more than $2,100. 

Song of the night: "Once in a Lifetime," Talking Heads. And you may ask yourself, well - how did I get here?

Send Eric O. Scott to Iceland!

I'm a writer, scholar, and Pagan whose work appears on sites like The Wild Hunt, Killing the Buddha, PaganSquare, and Patheos. My first novel, The Lives of the Apostates, came out through Moon Books last year. I'm also a PHD student in English at the University of Missouri - Columbia. I've been accepted into the University of Minnesota's Summer Icelandic program, which will be an incredible aid to my development as a writer and a scholar. Unfortunately, it comes with a $3,000 price tag, which I can't afford on my own. Which, hopefully, is where you come in!

My creative work focuses on my experiences as a second-generation Pagan; I was raised by members of a Wiccan coven in St. Louis, Missouri. I try to blend literary aesthetics with insight into the Pagan condition. My academic work brings in study of the medieval period, especially Iceland during the Saga Age.

The Icelandic language is very rarely taught in the United States, so this is one of the few opportunities I'll have to learn it. Despite how hard it is to find courses in Icelandic, the language is vital to studying Old Norse literature. Learning this language will be the best advantage I can have as a Norse scholar.

My ambition is to spend a year of my dissertation phase living in Iceland and collecting material for a book on Icelandic Asatru. This trip is also vital for making contacts who can support my work later on when I return for a longer stay.

What The Money Goes Toward

The cost of tuition, room, board, and airfare for the program is $3,000. That covers the classes, my lodging in Iceland, and my travel expenses. There are other expenses, such as lodging for the three weeks I'll be spending in Minneapolis, but I have some friends who are graciously offering to put me up there. Should I raise more than that, the money will go towards visiting more historical sites in Iceland, traveling to meet acquaintances, and, well, eating.

The Results

My creative work has always been rooted in my personal experiences, and this will be no different. I plan to write a series of columns and essays based on my experiences, good and bad, during this trip, which you will see on The Wild Hunt, Killing the Buddha, and elsewhere. By Yule, I plan to turn this all into a short ebook, which I will make available to all my gracious donors.

I've made a few perks available, including an acknowledgement in the ebook, a postcard from Iceland, and even the ultimate prize: I'll run a session of the Sagas of the Icelanders Roleplaying Game for you and up to four friends. You will be the envy of all nerd-dom; unfortunately, if the sagas teach us anything, it's that envy usually results in blood oaths.

All perk levels include the rewards for the lower donation amounts, too.

story:
Typical Sob Story:

First of all, I don't have the capability to make a video. I do hope you take the time to read.

I've never really been one to ask people for much of anything. In fact, I'm typcially the guy who would much rather starve for a day than muster the words to ask someone for any food. Honestly, if it wasn't for the few good friends I've made over the years, this last last nine months would have probably killed me. I honestly don't know why I'm typing this or even asking complete strangers for anything. In my mind you didn't even click the link to come to this page.

There's just something in this moment telling me not to give up.

Not this time.

You, the complete stranger, are the only thing creating a flicker of optimism in my life right now. It seems fitting we would get to some stuff about me, but before I describe the last year of my life to you or tell you what good things money could do for me. I think maybe you should get to know me - the real me.

I am only twenty-one years old.

I am a writer. Not like those people you know who say they want to someday be a writer, but a mildly genuine writer - as in I'm actually getting published places. I write both dark literary and horror fiction under the pen name Laramore Black. I don't think my real name is vitally important at this current juncture, but all contributors will deserve to know it - that's certain.

In the last year I have accomplished many things for being a poor American Midwest nobody. It's clear to me now that the need to be something to somone - anyone - is one of the only things that kept me going at times. 

To begin, with $17 and a half-broken netbook I have built one of the largest upcoming markets for noir fiction on the internet.

You can see this is true here: http://slityourwristsmagazine.com

Don't let the name scare you. It's really not as terrible as it sounds. It's a website that for the most part simply supports art. Be it writing, photography, artwork, or music. It's still in sort of an embryonic status, but has already surpassed I'd say 90% of the online market in readership.

The idea for the site isn't completely original, but what is, is that it was built from my past experiences. It's an internet hub of people the world has forced to think shouldn't exist anymore. That can be a lot of things though, a controversial opinion, someone always stepped on, the artists left in this world a capitalist society breaks - or someone like me, who is all of the above.

It may not be your cup of tea. You may even hate some of the things myself or people I have staffed have wrote. Maybe dark fiction just isn't your thing. The one thing I can hope anyone can agree on though is an outlet for anyone is a good thing. Any support for creative works is a good thing.

I've also begun doing really good things with the platform.

For instance I am putting together what is called an anthology, which is a collection of short stories from various authors. Kind of like a music sampler, but with writing if you aren't familar with it. The one I'm putting together with SYW has already recieved a ton of submissions from upper mid-list authors and even talented unknowns. This one specifically is called Shock & Appall and is completely for charity.

It's kind of darkly-humorous and ironic that all proceeds will be going to help one person. The profits will go to one person through the organization WorldVision. The reason why may simply be because I can feel empathy for a kid with nothing. To imagine what it'd be like for some kind stranger to step in and help change everything.

You could say I plan to pay it forward to someone the best I can.

Outside of these pursuits and even in the struggle of my daily life I have accomplished quite a bit as a writer. I am a blogger for the Imperial Youth Review. An anthology I was in called Nova Parade is up for a Spinetingler Award. Various amounts of my poetry and stories have been published, or are set to be published in publications across the web. One future publication happens to be a novel excerpt form my someday to be released novel, Autophonomania at a bigger site known as DarkMedia in February. 

Autophonomania is a fictional retelling of my battle with suicidal depression. A novel already being talked about amongst publishers. I've also been invited to release a poetry compilation with another press. Really, I think I'm still being modest when I say I have accomplished more than most people my age. I think given the opportunity I could accomplish much more though. Which is why I want to go back to school and have better surroundings.

Something that has probably crossed your mind in reading this is: where are your parents? Well, quite frankly I haven't seen my father in over two years and only recently began a new relationship with my mother. In a family with two boys, three sisters, and three nieces though, you could say my finances are the least of anyone's concerns.

It also leaves no room in a house for someone who left the nest at an early age.

In the last couple of years I have gone through various unfortunate events. Things like the largest tornado that destroyed half my city, a nasty young divorce, that discovery most people prefer chemicals over friendship, and months of struggling with being homeless.

There were times I had to walk 8 miles every day just for a place to sleep. Some days all I ate was a single $1 McDonald's menu item a friend of mine snuck me while I sat in the lobby looking for jobs, reading SYW submissions, and cranking out poem/short story drafts. There were times I sat outside of random businesses with no phone, nowhere to go, in both the heat of the summer and the cold of winter - without a single stranger asking me if I was even okay. No one to really rely on. Just me, a backpack, a half-broken netbook, and two outfits.

Unlike I imagine most people have, there wasn't and isn't anyone to turn to for help. Hell, you can't even sign yourself into a mental hospital when transient it turns out. Luckily, I am in a moderatively better state currently, but it doesn't look like it will last long.

I have had close to five job interviews in the last six months and every one of them haven't hired me. I don't know if it's simply the ongoing depression somehow showing through all those online personality tests, maybe they see something's wrong with me when I come in, maybe they see through the faked positive eyes. No reliable transportation doesn't help my case either, I suppose. I don't know.

What I do know though is this path in life has changed me.

Today I recieved an email that shattered my hopes of this being the last year I have to live like this. An email stating my financial aid reinstatement was disapproved. That their terms and conditions for me to come back would be to pay for a semester out of my own pocket. Which in poor and on the verge of being homeless again terms that means, "Your future is doomed and we don't care!"

The problem I have with this is I am a storyteller - and like any real writer, I know the truth isn't what Hollywood movies tend to show. I know that email was a ripple to possibly begin the end of my story. That if I don't do things to counteract it, the worst has yet begun.

This is my first, probably failing attempt at that.

 

How You Can Help:

Donating, obviously - but I will give you the details below.

It's pretty simple, $950 would be enough to take a couple online courses. This would be the minimum I would need. Regardless of where life takes me I could probably handle a couple courses, even if that means walking miles to the nearest wifi or whatever. A couple good grades in these classes would be enough to raise my GPA back to get financial aid my next returning semester. Getting financial aid back means I can live in the dorms, that I have guaranteed meals, finally focus on my education, and write in a more stress free manner.

The maximum I would ask for is closer to $5500. This would be enough that within a couple weeks I could move back into the dorms and become a full-time student. Anything beyond that would simply be put toward my well being (clothes, food, etc.) and marketing the charities of my own.

 

How Can This Work?

My school doesn't require tuition to be paid until the end of January, or for a TuitionPay plan to be intact. I'm going to start classes next week anyway, without books or supplies. The next week or two will decide my plans with how this crowd sourcing goes.

If it stays below $950 I will have to drop my courses and I will put the money toward promoting my charity anthology. If it hits the maximum I will follow through with living on campus and enrolling in more classes. If it ends somewhere between, I will attempt to do full-time enrollment status and live on campus by trying to get into a work-study/TuitionPay program to pay for the rest over time.

 

Note: I don't have a proper bank account to verify a paypal account, but you can send any amount to slityourwristsezine@gmail.com and I will still give the listed rewards.

That can be a lot of things though, a controversial opinion, someone always stepped on, the artists left in this world a capitalist society breaks - or someone like me, who is all of the above.
It may not be your cup of tea. You may even hate some of the things myself or people I have staffed have wrote. Maybe dark fiction just isn't your thing. The one thing I can hope anyone can agree on though is an outlet for anyone is a good thing. Any support for creative works is a good thing.
I've also begun doing really good things with the platform.
For instance I am putting together what is called an anthology, which is a collection of short stories from various authors. Kind of like a music sampler, but with writing if you aren't familar with it. The one I'm putting together with SYW has already recieved a ton of submissions from upper mid-list authors and even talented unknowns. This one specifically is called Shock & Appall and is completely for charity.
It's kind of darkly-humorous and ironic that all proceeds will be going to help one person. The profits will go to one person through the organization WorldVision. The reason why may simply be because I can feel empathy for a kid with nothing. To imagine what it'd be like for some kind stranger to step in and help change everything.
You could say I plan to pay it forward to someone the best I can.
Outside of these pursuits and even in the struggle of my daily life I have accomplished quite a bit as a writer. I am a blogger for the Imperial Youth Review. An anthology I was in called Nova Parade is up for a Spinetingler Award. Various amounts of my poetry and stories have been published, or are set to be published in publications across the web. One future publication happens to be a novel excerpt form my someday to be released novel, Autophonomania at a bigger site known as DarkMedia in February. 
Autophonomania is a fictional retelling of my battle with suicidal depression. A novel already being talked about amongst publishers. I've also been invited to release a poetry compilation with another press. Really, I think I'm still being modest when I say I have accomplished more than most people my age. I think given the opportunity I could accomplish much more though. Which is why I want to go back to school and have better surroundings.
Something that has probably crossed your mind in reading this is: where are your parents? Well, quite frankly I haven't seen my father in over two years and only recently began a new relationship with my mother. In a family with two boys, three sisters, and three nieces though, you could say my finances are the least of anyone's concerns.
It also leaves no room in a house for someone who left the nest at an early age.
In the last couple of years I have gone through various unfortunate events. Things like the largest tornado that destroyed half my city, a nasty young divorce, that discovery most people prefer chemicals over friendship, and months of struggling with being homeless.
There were times I had to walk 8 miles every day just for a place to sleep. Some days all I ate was a single $1 McDonald's menu item a friend of mine snuck me while I sat in the lobby looking for jobs, reading SYW submissions, and cranking out poem/short story drafts. There were times I sat outside of random businesses with no phone, nowhere to go, in both the heat of the summer and the cold of winter - without a single stranger asking me if I was even okay. No one to really rely on. Just me, a backpack, a half-broken netbook, and two outfits.
Unlike I imagine most people have, there wasn't and isn't anyone to turn to for help. Hell, you can't even sign yourself into a mental hospital when transient it turns out. Luckily, I am in a moderatively better state currently, but it doesn't look like it will last long.
I have had close to five job interviews in the last six months and every one of them haven't hired me. I don't know if it's simply the ongoing depression somehow showing through all those online personality tests, maybe they see something's wrong with me when I come in, maybe they see through the faked positive eyes. No reliable transportation doesn't help my case either, I suppose. I don't know.
What I do know though is this path in life has changed me.
Today I recieved an email that shattered my hopes of this being the last year I have to live like this. An email stating my financial aid reinstatement was disapproved. That their terms and conditions for me to come back would be to pay for a semester out of my own pocket. Which in poor and on the verge of being homeless again terms that means, "Your future is doomed and we don't care!"
The problem I have with this is I am a storyteller - and like any real writer, I know the truth isn't what Hollywood movies tend to show. I know that email was a ripple to possibly begin the end of my story. That if I don't do things to counteract it, the worst has yet begun.
This is my first, probably failing attempt at that.
 
How You Can Help:
Donating, obviously - but I will give you the details below.
It's pretty simple, $950 would be enough to take a couple online courses. This would be the minimum I would need. Regardless of where life takes me I could probably handle a couple courses, even if that means walking miles to the nearest wifi or whatever. A couple good grades in these classes would be enough to raise my GPA back to get financial aid my next returning semester. Getting financial aid back means I can live in the dorms, that I have guaranteed meals, finally focus on my education, and write in a more stress free manner.
The maximum I would ask for is closer to $5500. This would be enough that within a couple weeks I could move back into the dorms and become a full-time student. Anything beyond that would simply be put toward my well being (clothes, food, etc.) and marketing the charities of my own.
 
How Can This Work?
My school doesn't require tuition to be paid until the end of January, or for a TuitionPay plan to be intact. I'm going to start classes next week anyway, without books or supplies. The next week or two will decide my plans with how this crowd sourcing goes.
If it stays below $950 I will have to drop my courses and I will put the money toward promoting my charity anthology. If it hits the maximum I will follow through with living on campus and enrolling in more classes. If it ends somewhere between, I will attempt to do full-time enrollment status and live on campus by trying to get into a work-study/TuitionPay program to pay for the rest over time.
 
Note: I don't have a proper bank account to verify a paypal account, but you can send any amount to slityourwristsezine@gmail.com and I will still give the listed rewards.

story:
Short Summary

I figured my eighth birthday would come and go as the others had, little did I know I would receive a gift that sparked a fire within my soul. Within a small, discreet yellow envelope my parents placed the key to my future, a library card. The library card took me on a magic carpet ride through space and time with nobody but the characters as my companions and the author as my tour guide. My afternoons and weekends were spent surrounded by mounds of classic novels with my cassette player and a pair of headphones to drown out my world so that I could be enveloped within another. These worlds opened the gateway to the possibility of creating my own and brought about the revelation of what I could do when I put a pen to paper. 

As my creativity grew so did my love for the written word. The library card opened the door for my individuality to flourish and exceed my own personal expectations but it wasn't until my freshman year of college that I explored the realm of short stories and fiction writing. On my own I wrote short stories, novellas and poems; eventually I pushed myself to achieve as much as I possibly could in regards to my writing and to begin work on my novel. I found myself developing an ability and passion required for thinking outside the box and integrated it with my inherent creativity.
During my evaluation of various masters programs in Creative Writing, I found more success in overseas programs. Studying and traveling abroad has long been one of my objectives and to be able experience the rich and varied cultures of other communities would enhance my understanding of the world's many diverse artistic perspectives. Firsthand knowledge of the international industry would fill the spaces inherent in a purely domestic perspective. By traveling and studying abroad, I would nurture a greater appreciation for the depth of the arts and writing industry and while also gaining the additional experience necessary to distinguish my skills within the business of publishing. The opportunity to study in an international setting will additionally provide the experience of working with people of diverse cultures, thoughts, and talents. To achieve the level defined by my personal career aspirations, it is essential to experience the world of writing at the international level.

Serious consideration for effective and future positions in the industry of a person's choice often requires a master degree within the discipline. Pursuing graduate study in Creative Writing will enhance and define an in-depth knowledge of the components, the management, and the creative and cultural aspects within the industry itself. A rigorous curriculum will provide a deeper understanding and appreciation of this industry's precise and demanding nature. Being a cultural epicenter and a place to call home to literary geniuses such as Charles Dickens, Aldous Huxley, Lewis Carroll, Christopher Marlowe and more, it was obvious that to pursue this dream England was an obvious choice. Random House, HarperCollins and BBC Books (BBC Publishing) are the three firms I have always aspired to work with. Their esteemed resume of accomplished literary artists is one that any company should envy and something I someday hope to be a part of. A friend of mine once said, "Opportunities within the industry are constantly defined and formulated by those willing to reach beyond established boundaries; to challenge personal limitations." and throughout my journey I will always tread to the edge of my comfort, breathe deep, and step beyond. 

What We Need & What You Get

In order to achieve my dream I'll need some outside help!

  • My total cost of attendance is roughly ₤17,000 and I'm only asking for about half of my tuition (Thankfully graduate school in the UK is only 1 year instead of 2)!
  • $13,000 is my minimum goal but I'm hoping to supercede this in order to help with the rest of the tuition as well as travel expenses.

The Impact

If I am able to achieve this dream I wil have succeeded at what I have been pushing for since I was 10 years old; the publication of my first novel. No matter the amount, from $1-100, any donations will help get me closer to the job of a lifetime in the city of my dreams. If you are in a financial bind and can't donate I totally understand (I lived of Ramen noodles for a good portion of my year) but PLEASE don't hesitate to spread the word in any way possible. I will also be accepting prayers, well wishes and positive joo joo in full force :)

Blessings to all who venture onto this page.

story:
Je demande de l'aide afin de pouvoir acheter une adresse web .com, l'hébergement, avoir la chance de le mettre sur iTunes, Google Play Kiosque et même d'avoir la chance d'en faire la distribution dans les librairies ou ailleurs en version papier. La littérature fait partie de nos vies et mérite de se faire connaitre par le plus de gens possible. Entrevues d'auteurs, avis, sorties littéraires et plus... seront mis de l'avant dans ce magazine. Un projet qui me tient à coeur et que chaque dollars mis pour ce projet sera investi que pour cela. 

Entre 5$ et 99$ j'offre le 1er numéro gratuitement.  Ceux qui donneront + de 100$ auront la chance d'avoir leur nom ou bannière d'entreprise dans le 1er numéro.  

Pour voir à quoi ressemble un numéro :

Voici le dernier numéro à ce jour : #5 - VLE


Merci à tous!

--------------------------------------------------------------------

I ask for help in order to buy a .com web address, web hosting, have the chance to put it on iTunes, Google Play kiosk and even have the chance to make the distribution in bookstores or elsewhere in print. Literature is part of our lives and deserves to be known by many people as possible. Authors interviews, opinions, literary outings and more ... will be put forward in this magazine. A project close to my heart and each dollar put in this project than will be invested for this.

Between $ 5 and $ 99 I offer the first free number. Those who give $ 100 + will have the chance to have their name or company banner in the first number.

To see what looks like a number:

Here is the latest edition to date:  #5 - VLE (click on link)

Thank you all!

story:
My name is Rasha Hamid. I am a third generation teacher and children's picture books are one of the great loves of my life. 

Children's books about Sudan remain few and far between, and mostly they are about war. (Go ahead, check out this search for picture books about Sudan.)

Several years ago, I was teaching six and seven year olds at an international school in Sudan. At the beginning of a unit of study about Sudan, I asked the children what they already knew about our home country, and they said it was dry, hot, dirty, dusty, and ugly. I sought out picture books to give them a different perspective, but there were few appropriate for young children. We decided then to create our own book, inspired by Christopher Myers' beautiful book Black Cat, illustrated with our photographs of Sudan. We called our book Kadisa, using the Sudanese word for cat. 

That book inspired Kadisa كديسة. 

Kadisa كديسة introduces children to Sudan through stunning images of the magnificent and the mundane, with text in English and Sudanese Arabic. Lyrical, conversational text takes the reader through much of the country, and a glossary at the end introduces a few Sudanese Arabic words. Sudan's King of Jazz and visual artist, Sharhabil Ahmed contributed his whimsical cat drawings to the illustrations. Several Sudanese photographers shared gorgeous shots of Sudan. In this time of visa bans and Islamophobic rhetoric, Kadisa كديسة offers an alternative image of Sudan - one that is full of light, color and beauty.

Christopher Myers wrote, in this powerful op-ed, "[Children] see books less as mirrors and more as maps. They are indeed searching for their place in the world, but they are also deciding where they want to go. They create, through the stories they’re given, an atlas of their world, of their relationships to others, of their possible destinations." Getting this book out into the world would invite all children to explore and fall in love with Sudan.

In addition to the print version, a planned audiobook version will allow children to hear both English and Sudanese Arabic text read aloud. 

Kadisa كديسة is now available!

  • Order a copy for someone you love!
  • Use Indiegogo's share tools to get the word out to your networks!
  • Tell all the teachers, librarians, and folks with kids that they need a copy of Kadisa كديسة !

story:
Sunny is an attorney, budding photographer and the chief navigator on our overland journey. Karin is a professional systems engineer and has been the primary driver on our journey from Nashville, across the United States, through Mexico, Central America and back.

In 2015, we left our jobs and sold everything we owned to drive from Nashville, Tennessee to the southern tip of South America.  Before we left, we were repeatedly discouraged by others and by the media.  Everyone said these were not safe countries for women to travel in, that a trip like this would be too physically demanding for women, one person even said we would come home in pine boxes. 

Despite these messages, we overcame our fears and got on the road.  It's been two years and through our travels we discovered SO MANY WOMEN  living lives on the road.  They travel in cars, trucks, motorcycles, vans and bicycles.  They go places most people would never dare to go. They travel by themselves, with spouses, with children, with pets, with each other.  They are corporate professionals, hippies, moms, writers, photographers, yoginis, chefs – they are a lot of things but currently, they are OVERLANDERS.

In this book you will DISCOVER:

  • Who They Are
  • What They Drive
  • Where They Are From
  • What They Have Learned
  • ABSOLUTE INSPIRATION combined with beautiful photographs from around the world.

We want to introduce you to these women.  They WILL mesmerize you, they will inspire you – they are heroes.

What We Need & What You Get

"I Can. I Will: Women Overlanding the World" will not just inspire you through the adventures of these unconventional women, but it is also a collection of photos taken in places that most people don't get an opportunity to see and stories of women doing things that most people will never do. 

The Impact:
Your contribution will allow us to hire and collaborate with a professional editor, a talented designer, and work with the best printer to provide you with a beautiful book that will give these photos the presentation they deserve.

"Why a book for women?" - because we are women.  Because we have been on our own incredible journey and it has made us understand how important it is for women to find empowerment in witnessing other women living their lives outside of societal expectations. 

But it’s not just for adventurers. It’s for anyone who knows there is more to life than working 9-5, making dinner, watching tv and going to bed every day.  It's for anyone who has looked back at their year and found themselves unable to distinguish one day from the next. 

We wanted to create an artifact, a springboard. A beautiful thing that takes up space in your life, and nudges you with its presence, urging you to travel and experience the world with an open mind and fresh eyes.  

The campaign is priced to make the book as accessible as possible. It includes free shipping in the USA, and similarly subsidized shipping overseas.

Once funding is met, we are hoping the book will be ready in time for Christmas.

Risks & Challenges:
Risks are low.  We are two professional women with a proven track record for completing complex projects. The biggest challenge is the remote locations these women are in, but they have come down from mountains, out of the jungle and through the desert to share their stories, photographs and life-lessons with us. 

Many of the women involved in this book are published authors, professional photographers and popular writers. 

Other Ways You Can Help
Share this campaign!  A share is as valuable to us as a contribution.  We appreciate your support in any way you can give it. 


About The Rewards:

The Book:  We will provide you with a high-quality, full color, photo-rich, 200+ page hardcover coffee-table book full of breathtaking photos and stories of women traveling the world by car, truck, van, motorcycle and bicycle.  I can guarantee you that a collection like this DOES NOT EXIST ANYWHERE ELSE!

 

Overlander Coloring Book: Coloring isn't just for kids but for the creative adventurer in all of us.  We have created several coloring pages from pictures throughout our overland travels and of rigs we have encountered on the road. 


Guatemalan Friendship Bracelet*:  These bracelets are really beautiful. Handmade by local Guatemalans, we purchased a variety of colors and styles while in Antigua. 


Handmade Mexican Leather Cuff*: Each handmade cuff was made individually, out of fine Mexican leather.  We picked out each one ourselves, making sure each one was unique in both color and design,  directly from the shop of a Mexican leather artisan.  


Guatemalan Mini-Masks*: When we saw these tiny masks at Lago de Atitlan, we had to have them. Each one is between 1 and 2 inches tall. The unique art is 100% hand painted and hand carved, made with love and excellent attention to detail by Guatemalan artisans from the town of Chichicastenango. The wood these masks are made from is conscious and approved by the Guatemalan forestry department. 

 

E-book version of the book:  Downloadable version of our book for electronic devices.


30-minute Skype Session w/ the Vagabroads:  Ask us anything!  We'll tell you anything you want to know about how we started our adventure, the gear we took, stories from the road, etc.


20-minute Skype Session w/ a Woman Featured in the Book:   Meet the women!  Depending upon who is available and not on a mountain somewhere, we will choose a woman featured within the book to speak with you over Skype.

*Each perk is "while supplies last" and may be substituted for another reward of equal or better value. 

DON'T FORGET TO CHECK OUT THE CAMPAIGN VIDEO AND PHOTO GALLERY!

 

Follow us and keep in touch!

Facebook:  https://www.facebook.com/vagabroads

Instagram:  https://www.instagram.com/thevagabroads

Website:   https://vagabroads.com
